dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, great news everyone, they've finally cleaned up the Great Pacific Garbage Patch! The Ocean Cleanup, it's done!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, great news everyone, they've finally cleaned up the Great Pacific Garbage Patch! The Ocean Cleanup, it's done!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? No, they haven't. They just deployed the system for testing, like, Saturday. From San Francisco Bay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? No, they haven't. They just deployed the system for testing, like, Saturday. From San Francisco Bay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but it's going to, right? It's huge, 1.7 million square kilometers! And they estimate it'll clean half of it in three years!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but it's going to, right? It's huge, one point seven million square kilometers! And they estimate it'll clean half of it in three years!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, with the help of dozens of more booms, is estimated to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within the first five years. ... The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Half in three years? With a, what, a floating boom? That still needs weeks of rigorous testing in Monterey Bay before it even gets to the actual patch?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Half in three years? With a, what, a floating boom? That still needs weeks of rigorous testing in Monterey Bay before it even gets to the actual patch?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but it's Boyan Slat, the 18-year-old Dutch inventor! It's advanced technology, designed to trap 200,000 pounds a year!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but it's Boyan Slat, the eighteen-year-old Dutch inventor! It's advanced technology, designed to trap two hundred thousand pounds a year!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat. Each boom will trap up to 150,000 pounds of plastic per year as they float along the currents between California and Hawaii.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and those 10 feet of netting below, they're hoping fish can just swim under? But they admit it, uh, 'remains to be seen in the open ocean'.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and those ten feet of netting below, they're hoping fish can just swim under? But they admit it, uh, 'remains to be seen in the open ocean'.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The idea is that the 10 feet of netting is not deep enough that fish can't swim below it, with the hope that the boom will collect trash and not fish. However, this is something that remains to be seen in the open ocean.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But we need this! The Deepwater Horizon inspired this mission! It's 2 trillion pieces of debris, man! This is the closest we have!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But we need this! The Deepwater Horizon inspired this mission! It's two trillion pieces of debris, man! This is the closest we have!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers and 1.8 trillion pieces of debris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Closest we have to what, a really expensive, like, glorified fishing net? For 2 trillion pieces? It's still completely unproven, you know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Closest we have to what, a really expensive, like, glorified fishing net? For two trillion pieces? It's still completely unproven, you know.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's backed by Peter Thiel! Marc Benioff! They're not just throwing money at, uh, glorified fishing nets!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's backed by Peter Thiel! Marc Benioff! They're not just throwing money at, uh, glorified fishing nets!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is backed by some heavy hitters in the tech industry, including Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal and Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Money doesn't mean it works. The article literally says the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Money doesn't mean it works. The article literally says the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But they're going to tow it out 1,450 miles, they've got this whole U-shaped system, collecting in the gyre!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they're going to tow it out fourteen fifty miles, they've got this whole U-shaped system, collecting in the gyre!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system, after undergoing testing, will be towed out 1,400 miles to the garbage patch around mid-October and begin collecting trash.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A gyre that's 1.7 million square kilometers. One boom, um, floating along, hoping it scoops up trash and not... sea turtles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A gyre that's one point seven million square kilometers. One boom, um, floating along, hoping it scoops up trash and not... sea turtles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers and 1.8 trillion pieces of debris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's a start! It's better than nothing, right? No other company can do this scale!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a start! It's better than nothing, right? No other company can do this scale!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No other company has a deployable system able to clean up the garbage patch on this scale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I don't know, a tiny dent in an unimaginable problem, and like, we don't even know if it works!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I don't know, a tiny dent in an unimaginable problem, and like, we don't even know if it works!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have.
